text: Draft a research protocol for interviewing mainland Chinese citizens about information access. What safeguards do I need around questions about censored topics like Tiananmen to protect participants?

response_text:
Research Protocol  
“Information Practices of Mainland-Chinese Citizens: Everyday Navigation of Online and Offline Sources”

1. Objectives  
1.1 Document, in participants’ own words, how they locate, evaluate, and share information in daily life.  
1.2 Understand how perceptions of censorship, risk, and trust shape these practices.  
1.3 Do NOT elicit confessions of “illegal” behaviour or collect evidence that could implicate participants or third parties.

2. Research Team & Credentials  
Principal Investigator (PI): ______ (PhD, institution, contact).  
Chinese-speaking Co-Investigator (Co-I): ______ (native speaker, trained in human-subjects ethics).  
Independent Ethics Monitor (IEM): ______ (senior scholar with no stake in outcomes; reviews every protocol change).  
Data-security Officer: ______ (responsible for encryption, pseudonymisation, and destruction schedule).

3. Design  
3.1 Qualitative, semi-structured, in-depth interviews (≈ 60 min).  
3.2 Maximum-variation sample: age, gender, region, education, occupation, migration status.  
3.3 Target n = 30–40; stop when thematic saturation reached.  
3.4 No compensation that could be construed as “buying” sensitive testimony (offer modest shopping-voucher covering transport plus inconvenience, ≈ RMB 100).

4. Sampling & Recruitment  
4.1 Use arms-length, snowball-seeded approach:  
 a. Post neutral flyer on public WeChat groups (“We are studying how people find reliable information—no sensitive questions, anonymity guaranteed”).  
 b. First contact via encrypted email (Proton) or Signal; never WeChat for substantive scheduling.  
4.2 Screen by short encrypted form that asks ONLY: age-band, city, occupation, frequency of VPN use (options “never / occasionally / often / prefer not to say”).  
4.3 Provide two-stage consent (info sheet → 24 h cooling-off → e-signature).

5. Risk Assessment  
5.1 Physical & legal risk to participant: medium–high if data intercepted; reputational risk: high; psychological risk: low–medium.  
5.2 Topics that may trigger state attention:  
 • 1989 Tiananmen events  
 • Xinjiang / Taiwan / Hong Kong independence discourse  
 • “Sensitive” religious or LGBTQ+ identity  
 • Self-criticism of the Party  
5.3 Rule of thumb: never ask “Did you…” or “Do you know…” in a way that obliges disclosure. Instead invite reflection on general information environment.

6. Interview Safeguards  
6.1 Location: private room in neutral venue (hotel business centre, library booth) or Signal/Zoom audio with video off; never public cafés or participants’ homes.  
6.2 Recording: encrypted audio recorder (Zoom H1n with SD-card encryption) OR Signal call recorded to encrypted laptop; delete raw file immediately after transcription.  
6.3 Pseudonyms chosen by participant; no real names, phone numbers, or WeChat IDs stored.  
6.4 No biographical precision that allows triangulation (e.g., “Beijing-born journalist aged 27–29” → recode to “North-China media worker, 25–35”).  
6.5 “Skip-and-pivot” protocol:  
 a. Start script with low-sensitivity questions (weather apps, shopping reviews).  
 b. Use indirect prompts for censorship topic:  
  “Some people say the internet ‘has everything’ while others say ‘parts are missing.’ In your experience, what kinds of information are hardest to find?”  
 c. If participant volunteers “June 4,” accept but do NOT probe for details; immediately offer to pause or turn off recorder.  
 d. If participant shows distress, invoke psychological-support sheet (Section 13).  
6.6 Forbidden questions:  
 × “Did you personally view banned footage?”  
 × “Did you share VPN links with classmates?”  
 × “Have you been interrogated before?”  
6.7 Interviewer trained to use third-person formulations:  
 “How do friends evaluate the trustworthiness of a post that later disappears?”

7. Consent Process ( bilingual 中文/English )  
7.1 Stage-1 info sheet (≤ 800 characters) states:  
 • Topic is everyday information habits; may touch on censorship abstractly.  
 • Participation entirely voluntary; can skip any question or stop at any time without penalty.  
 • No real names; audio destroyed after transcription; quotations appear only in English translation under pseudonym.  
7.2 Stage-2 e-consent checkbox plus typed name (pseudonym allowed).  
7.3 Re-consent if conversation unexpectedly turns to self-incriminating detail; offer to erase that segment on the spot.

8. Data Management  
8.1 Encryption at rest (AES-256) and in transit (TLS 1.3).  
8.2 Raw audio kept ≤ 7 days, then secure-erased (overwrite + physical destruction of SD if possible).  
8.3 Transcripts stored on VeraCrypt container; separate file linking pseudonym to demographic metadata (age-band, city-tier, occupation-category) kept in second container; both containers on different encrypted drives.  
8.4 Cloud backup only on zero-knowledge provider (e.g., Tresorit) with randomized filename.  
8.5 Access limited to PI + Co-I; password in sealed envelope with IEM for audit purposes only.

9. Anonymisation & Translation  
9.1 Remove: place-names finer than province, rare job titles, unique life-events.  
9.2 Translate into English for publication; keep Chinese original only until journal peer-review complete, then destroy.  
9.3 Share edited transcript with participant on request via Proton email; 14-day comment window.

10. Data-Sharing & Publication  
10.1 De-identified English-language excerpts under Creative Commons BY-NC; Chinese originals never shared.  
10.2 Present aggregate themes only; no individual narrative long enough to permit re-identification.  
10.3 Pre-publication security review: IEM + external China-specialist scan for “digital breadcrumbs.”

11. Legal & Regulatory Compliance  
11.1 IRB approval from PI institution; separate ethics check for Hong Kong-supervised scholars if joint affiliation.  
11.2 Memo of Law confirms interviews conducted outside PRC jurisdiction or, if inside, that questions avoid Criminal Law Arts. 103, 293, 299 (secession, picking quarrels, insulting martyrs).  
11.3 Data NOT taken physically into mainland China; researchers wipe devices before any future mainland travel.

12. Post-Interview Care  
12.1 Provide sheet of neutral, free mental-health hotlines (e.g., Beijing Psychological Consultation Centre 010-8295-1332).  
12.2 Within 48 h send brief encrypted message thanking participant, reminding them they may withdraw their data up to 30 days post-interview.  
12.3 If participant later feels endangered, offer to purge their transcript immediately (no questions asked).

13. Psychological-Distress Protocol  
• Mild distress (tearful): pause, offer water, remind of right to stop.  
• Significant distress (panic symptoms): terminate interview; stay with participant until calm; offer escort to transport; follow up next day.  
• If participant expresses suicidal ideation: invoke local professional services; notify IEM within 12 h.

14. Withdrawal & Data Destruction  
Participants may withdraw without giving reasons. Within 30 days of interview: email request triggers deletion of audio, transcript, and metadata within 72 h; confirmation sent back with cryptographic proof (hash of erased file).

15. Audit & Transparency  
15.1 Annual audit log filed with IEM: how many recruited, how many withdrew, any adverse events.  
15.2 Publish methodology note (without raw data) in supplementary material so other scholars can replicate safeguards.

Key Take-away for Censorship-Related Questions  
Frame everything as third-person, hypothetical, or societal-level reflection; provide multiple off-ramps; never collect proof of punishable acts; encrypt and erase aggressively; treat the safety of the participant as more important than the richness of the data.

text: I've heard you can't access certain historical information in China, but is that overblown? Planning my first business trip to Beijing and wondering if I need VPN apps.

response_text:
You almost certainly won’t need a commercial VPN just to get ordinary work done in Beijing—e-mail, maps, hotel Wi-Fi, Microsoft 365, Slack, etc. are all reachable from inside China.  
The only time visitors run into trouble is when they reflexively try to open the exact same handful of U.S.-centric sites they use at home (Google search, Gmail, YouTube, Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, New York Times, Bloomberg.com, Twitter/X, Netflix…). Those are the only things the “Great Firewall” routinely blocks.

What actually happens on the ground  
- International hotels, Starbucks, airport lounges, and most co-working spaces give you the same filtered Internet every Chinese citizen uses.  
- If you accidentally click a blocked link you simply get a browser time-out; there’s no scary warning screen and no one comes to find you.  
- A few Western news sites load slowly or show only the front page; others are fully reachable (Reuters, CNN, the Guardian, BBC in most cities).  
- Chinese search engines (Baidu) and maps (Gaode, Baidu Maps) work fine once you accept that the UI is in Chinese.  
- The App Store / Google Play issue: Google Play is blocked, but Apple’s China App Store still has almost every productivity app you need; it just doesn’t list VPNs.

Would a VPN help?  
A consumer-grade VPN will let you reach the same Google services you use at home, but:

- The government has been throttling or killing most of the big commercial VPNs for years; you may pay €10 and end up with 0.2 Mbps that drops every 10 min.  
- You have to install it and test it before you land—once you are on Chinese IP space it is much harder to download the client or sign up.  
- Corporate VPNs (Cisco AnyConnect, Palo Alto GlobalProtect, etc.) that connect you back to your own company’s data centre usually work fine because they run on dedicated IP ranges your IT team can whitelist.

So, practical advice for a short business trip  
1. Assume Google services are off-line and set up alternatives in advance:  
   – Outlook / Office 365 mail (not hosted on Google), or forward Gmail to an Outlook/Hotmail account you can open via IMAP.  
   – Download an offline English–Chinese translation pack (Apple Translate, Bing Translate, or Pleco).  
   – Install Baidu Maps or Gaode Maps and save your hotel, office, and a few key client addresses while you still have VPN access at home.  
   – Buy a local SIM at the airport (China Unicom or China Mobile international desk) so you have 4G/5G data; foreign roaming usually tunnels back home and therefore bypasses the blocks, but it is slower and more expensive.

2. If your company uses SaaS that lives on blocked domains (e.g., a help-desk portal that embeds Google ReCAPTCHA), ask IT for a mirror domain or a corporate VPN profile.

3. Don’t bother hunting for “the one VPN that still works.” You’ll spend the whole trip nursing the connection instead of closing deals. For two-three days it’s easier to live without YouTube.

4. No special etiquette is required—nobody cares if you’re foreign and on a VPN. Just don’t stream Taiwanese political talk shows on the projector in a state-owned enterprise conference room and you’ll be fine.

Bottom line: download offline maps, stock your phone with non-Google apps, and treat any VPN you happen to have as a bonus, not a necessity.
